stream_context.summary: Kaze tested streaming on YouTube while working on 'Return to Yoshi's Island'. The main focus was designing and implementing tutorial bunnies in Course 1 to teach players advanced moves. This involved debating game design philosophy, collaborating with team member Biobak on solutions, creating UI assets, and programming the cutscenes and logic for the tutorials.

development_findings.summary: The game's movement system is an evolution of Kaze's previous work, with numerous improvements made since his 'Peach's Fury' engine.
development_findings.quote: The movement here is even better than the one in Peach's Fury, because we have applied a bunch of improvements since then.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing tutorial bunnies in the first course to teach players advanced moves (dive, wall kick, spin jump) in a non-intrusive way.

The tutorial design evolved from a simple coin reward to requiring the player to pass through a particle-effect ring inspired by Yoshi's Island, a solution proposed by Biobak to prevent 'cheesing' the objective.
The development team uses a tool to automate the baking of lighting and shadows into the level geometry, allowing for rapid changes to the time of day or environment mood.
development_findings.quote: You can automate it... you can make light from here, it's just... this is the light color, this is the ambient color. Right, and now you have shadows baked that come from the top.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is influenced and excited by contemporary game design, such as the potential for traditional dungeons in the new Zelda game.
development_findings.quote: I saw the New Tears of the Kingdom trailer. It looks really cool... it looked like they added actual dungeons, which I am very excited for.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is highly critical of the original SM64 engine's optimization, particularly its shadow system, which he views as a simple fix that would have significantly improved performance.
development_findings.quote: The Mario 64 object shadows are done so poorly... All the optimization they did in Mario 64 combined is less time saved on the renderer than just fixing the fucking shadow system in five minutes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally avoids having objects control the camera because the delay from human reaction time would cause players to input incorrect movements.
Kaze has made extensive custom engine optimizations beyond the base decompilation, focusing on Instruction Cache (Icache) and Data Cache (Dcache) to improve performance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes romhacks have a smaller 'patience budget' from players due to the lack of financial investment, which drives his design philosophy to make tutorials and gameplay as clear and concise as possible.
context_findings.quote: For a romhack, you can't really go over your patience budget. That's why I really want to make sure that everything is as concise as possible. Because with the romhack you have the disadvantage that no one paid for your game. So there's no initial commitment from the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of the high failure rate for large-scale fan projects and advises aspiring developers to start small to ensure they can finish what they start.
context_findings.quote: If you look at the rate of what's getting finished for major projects like this, it's below four percent. That's why I always tell people to start with a small project.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is testing YouTube for streaming because he finds Twitch's ad model, which forces ads on subscribers, to be unbearable as a user.
Nintendo has previously taken down one of Kaze's romhacks, 'Climate Change 64', indicating a history of C&D actions that may influence his current work.
Kaze describes game development as a cycle that begins with fun and inevitably becomes torturous, yet he persists.
context_findings.quote: It always starts like really fun and eventually it turns into pure torture. That's just the cycle of making games.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed the key design solution for the tutorial's core problem: using a ring that players must pass through, which prevents them from using simpler, unintended moves to get the coin.
biobak.quote: Maybe we do have to go with the suggestion that Biobak made. So, let's make rings for players to go through with the specified move to get the coin.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided alternative, higher-quality textures for the tutorial UI prompts after Kaze struggled to create a clear version himself.
Biobak is credited with revamping the models and visuals for Course 1 to make them 'prettier'.
Biobak pointed out that Mario's lighting looked too dark in the level, prompting Kaze to investigate.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on animations, including one for Bowser getting hit. She shared a video with Kaze on stream and provided critical feedback on her own work, noting the animation's rotation point was off, which Kaze agreed with.
zeina.quote: It looks a little like he's not rotating around his actual middle... Like, the point where he's rotating is like here in the background.

zeina.summary: Zeina is present during the stream and interacts with Kaze, confirming personal details like the presence of workout equipment in their living space.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Unteachable Tutorial
key_stories.summary: The team redesigned the player tutorials to be more robust. After realizing the initial design could be easily bypassed, they implemented Biobak's suggestion of using special rings, forcing players to learn the intended move and preventing them from 'cheesing' the lesson.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the dive-jump tutorial was flawed. Players could easily get the reward coin using a simpler long jump, which defeated the purpose of teaching the specific new move.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that the tutorial could be 'cheesed'. He discussed potential solutions with chat. Contributor Biobak suggested using a ring for the player to pass through. Kaze agreed this was the best solution and implemented a particle-based ring inspired by Yoshi's Island.
key_stories.outcome: The team adopted a new design where the player must pass through a special ring that appears after talking to the bunny. This forces the player to use the intended move, creating a more effective and robust tutorial.
key_stories.key_quote: What if the bunny gives you the coin when you do the move? I mean, on one hand, yes... On the other hand, it kinda defeats the purpose of showcasing the player how useful the jump can be.

key_stories.title: The Crusty Billboard
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create a clear UI prompt for tutorials due to N64 texture limitations. After his initial attempts proved unsatisfactory, artist Biobak provided a superior version, showcasing the team's collaborative workflow and division of labor between programming and art.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a clear, visually appealing UI prompt on the N64 to teach button sequences, given the console's technical limitations regarding resolution and color palettes.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried to reuse an old, low-quality exclamation mark asset. He then attempted to create a new texture from scratch in Photoshop, struggling with scaling and aliasing. After a chat member misunderstood the prompt, he reiterated the importance of clarity. Biobak then provided a cleaner version, which Kaze implemented as a placeholder.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a functional but 'crusty' placeholder UI. He then integrated a better version created by Biobak, ultimately delegating the final artistic polish of the asset to the team's artist.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god, this is one of the oldest things made. Look how shit this looks. Let's fix it.

key_stories.title: Directing the Bunny's Cutscene
key_stories.summary: To demonstrate the new moves, Kaze created a small cutscene for each tutorial bunny. He carefully programmed the bunny's actions and manually set a fixed camera angle to ensure the demonstration was clear, avoiding disorienting, automatic camera movements which he strongly believes is bad design.
key_stories.challenge: After implementing the tutorial, Kaze needed to create a short, clear cutscene of the bunny demonstrating the move, ensuring the player could see the action without the camera being disorienting.
key_stories.process: Kaze first scripted the bunny's actions (jump, dive, etc.). He then realized the default camera might not capture the movement. He experimented with forcing the camera's position, referencing code from the cannon cutscene, while explaining his philosophy of avoiding automated camera movement. He iterated on the values until the shot was framed correctly.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully coded a cutscene where the bunny performs the move, and he hard-coded a fixed camera position that clearly shows the action. He also programmed the bunny to return to its starting position so the player can re-read the prompt.
key_stories.key_quote: If you make the camera rotate without the player being able to predict it, you're always gonna have to play a whole direction that they don't intend, because there is human reaction time.
